title: Chipping, Hertfordshire
text:
Chipping is a <a href="hamlet%20%28place%29">hamlet</a> in the <a href="civil%20parish">civil parish</a> of <a href="Buckland%2C%20Hertfordshire">Buckland</a> in the <a href="East%20Hertfordshire">East Hertfordshire</a> district, in the county of <a href="Hertfordshire">Hertfordshire</a>, England. Situated along the <a href="A10%20road%20%28Great%20Britain%29">A10 road</a> (which follows the course of the Roman <a href="Ermine%20Street">Ermine Street</a>), Chipping was an early, but unsuccessful attempt to create a market town at the crossing of the <a href="River%20Rib">River Rib</a> by Ermine Street. 
Situated in a valley, Chipping lies approximately north of <a href="Buntingford">Buntingford</a> and south of <a href="Royston%2C%20Hertfordshire">Royston</a>. Chipping is situated half a mile west of the <a href="prime%20meridian">prime meridian</a>. Prior to 1750, Chipping was referred to as "New Chipping", today this name is rarely used.
History.
Early history.
The current settlement of Chipping first emerged along the former Roman Road <a href="Ermine%20Street">Ermine Street</a> as the manor of Pope's Hall (now Chipping Hall) then a part of Buckland village, as mentioned in the <a href="Doomsday%20Book">Doomsday Book</a>. Former earthworks, including a moat (all destroyed in the 1950s) inside Burhill Wood to the west of Chipping, could suggest an earlier <a href="Iron%20Age">Iron Age</a> settlement or hill fort, predating the present-day Chipping. 
Chipping as an independent settlement to Buckland developed around 1220 as "New Cheping" (later becoming New Chipping), due to its strategic location along Ermine Street as a final stop-off for passing traffic before confronting several steep hills whilst travelling between London and York, and later, London and Cambridge.
Chipping was the site of a market (every Friday) and fair (three days a year) from 1252 until 1360 before its transferral to nearby <a href="Buntingford">Buntingford</a> by <a href="Elizabeth%20de%20Burgh%2C%204th%20Countess%20of%20Ulster">Elizabeth de Burgh, 4th Countess of Ulster</a> the lord of the manor of Pope's Hall due to its dwindling trade caused by Buntingford's rapid growth compared to Chipping.
After 1700.
From 1700 until the mid-nineteenth century the main occupation of Chipping's residence was farming, working the dense woodland and farmland surrounding the village, whilst other villages served passing trade along <a href="Ermine%20Street">Ermine Street</a>. However, Chipping has always been overshadowed by its larger neighbours of <a href="Buntingford">Buntingford</a> to the south and <a href="Royston%2C%20Hertfordshire">Royston</a> to the north, with its population remaining small, it was never large enough for the construction of a church.
Sometime after its closure in 1360 the market was re-established, before it was finally closed in 1883. Until the late nineteenth-century Chipping was divided between the <a href="parish">parish</a> of <a href="Therfield">Therfield</a>, to the west side of <a href="Ermine%20Street">Ermine Street</a> and <a href="Buckland%2C%20Hertfordshire">Buckland</a> parish, to the east.
A <a href="Post%20mill">Post mill</a> was formerly situated on Mill Hill to the east of the village from around 1737 until 1838. The former <a href="public%20house">public house</a>, "The Royal Oak", was destroyed by fire sometime in the 1970s, its site now hosts the Cul-de-sac Royal Oak Close.
Today.
Population.
The population of Chipping in 1851 was 215, however, with the development of the railway, causing decreased road traffic and growing demand for industrial workers in cities, meant Chipping's population fell to below 100 by 1905. 
Today Chipping has around 50 houses with a population of around 125 to 150 as of 2011. The parish of <a href="Buckland%2C%20Hertfordshire">Buckland</a> and Chipping has a combined population of 274 as of 2011, with the population roughly split between both villages.
Local government.
Along with its neighbour <a href="Buckland%2C%20Hertfordshire">Buckland</a>, Chipping elects members to the Buckland and Chipping <a href="Parish%20councils%20in%20England">parish council</a>. 
Chipping is in the <a href="Buntingford">Buntingford</a> ward of the <a href="Hertfordshire%20County%20Council">Hertfordshire County Council</a> <a href="unitary%20authority">unitary authority</a>, which is responsible for all significant local government functions. Additionally, Chipping is within the Buntingford ward of <a href="East%20Hertfordshire%20District%20Council">East Hertfordshire District Council</a>, having two district councillors.
On the national level, Chipping is in the <a href="North%20East%20Hertfordshire%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">North East Hertfordshire</a> parliamentary constituency.
Landmarks.
Chipping has an array of historic and modern landmarks, with over half of Chipping's current housing being built since the turn of the twentieth century. Chipping also includes several historic buildings, thatched cottages and a public house, many of which date back to the 17th century and earlier. 
"The Countryman (Inn)" (formerly the "The Red Lion Inn" until 1975) is a 17th-century <a href="coaching%20inn">coaching inn</a>, built in 1663, it has operated as a public house since 1760. Situated in the centre of the village, "The Countryman" has hosted the yearly 'World Sausage Tossing Championship' every August since 2014.
Chipping also includes the <a href="manor%20house">manor house</a> of Chipping Hall (formerly Pope's Hall), with the current hall dating from the early eighteenth-century, the main hall, dovecot and walled gardens are constructed in early <a href="Georgian%20architecture">Georgian architecture</a> from red brick. The manor of Pope's Hall was inherited by <a href="Lionel%20of%20Antwerp%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Clarence">Lionel of Antwerp, 1st Duke of Clarence</a> from his wife <a href="Elizabeth%20de%20Burgh%2C%204th%20Countess%20of%20Ulster">Elizabeth de Burgh, 4th Countess of Ulster</a> after her death in 1363. On the north side of Chipping Hall is a large eighteenth-century farmyard, once apart of Chipping Hall farm, it was sold and converted into housing around 2007.
Chipping also includes a former Congregational Chapel which was constructed in 1844 and a former Mission Room constructed in 1878 for a cost of £380, both are now in private ownership. Six houses along Chipping's "Brookside" lane were some of the UK's first <a href="Public%20housing%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">council housing</a> constructed under the <a href="Housing%2C%20Town%20Planning%2C%20%26amp%3Bc.%20Act%201919">Addison Act</a> of 1919.
Toponym.
The name <a href="Chipping%20%28disambiguation%29">Chipping</a> likely derives from "ceapen", an <a href="Old%20English%20language">Old English</a> word meaning 'market', referring to the market hosted in Chipping between 1252 and 1360, though it is also possible the name rather derives from the <a href="Medieval%20English">Medieval English</a> word "chepynge" meaning 'long market square', supported by early references to Chipping as "New Cheping". <a href="Chipping%20%28disambiguation%29">Chipping</a> is a prefix name used by several places in <a href="England">England</a>, however, only <a href="Chipping%2C%20Lancashire">Chipping, Lancashire</a> shares the sole use of the name Chipping.
Chipping's historic name "New Chipping" used prior to 1750 (less commonly used until 1900) more specifically meaning 'new market'. The reason why "new" was dropped from Chipping's name is unknown, though this change was likely gradual, evolving from being "New Chipping" to just "Chipping" over several hundred years.
Geography.
Landscape.
Chipping is situated at the foot of three hills, to the north Chipping Hill, to the east Capons Hill and the west Mill Hill. Though historically Chipping was surrounded by dense woodland used for graving pigs and sheep, today only Capons Wood to the east and Burhill Wood to the west of the village survive (never have public right of way). College Wood (formerly adjacent to Capons Wood) was removed in the 1950s/60s, alongside the reduction in the size of Burhill Wood (around 80% of its total area) to make way for increased farmland.
The <a href="River%20Rib">River Rib</a> runs through the village, with one bridge (Chipping Bridge) across the <a href="A10%20road%20%28England%29">A10</a> and two fords along public footpaths crossing the river. 
The village of <a href="Buckland%2C%20Hertfordshire">Buckland</a> lies one mile north of Chipping, whilst the <a href="prime%20meridian">prime meridian</a> passes to the east of Chipping.
Wildlife.
The land surrounding Chipping is dominated by farmland growing <a href="Winter%20wheat">Winter wheat</a>, <a href="Rapeseed">Rapeseed</a>, <a href="Borage">Borage</a> and <a href="Vicia%20faba">Broad beans</a>. Such a habitat has meant farmland birds such as the <a href="grey%20partridge">grey partridge</a>, <a href="lapwing">lapwing</a>, <a href="Eurasian%20skylark">skylark</a>, <a href="yellowhammer">yellowhammer</a> and <a href="corn%20bunting">corn bunting</a> can be found along the many <a href="Bridle%20path">bridleways</a> and <a href="Rights%20of%20way%20in%20England%20and%20Wales">public footpaths</a> surrounding Chipping, even though these birds are declining nationally.
